title: The BBC wins big at the RTS Programme Awards 2024
body_text:
It was an incredible night for the BBC that celebrated the work of the extraordinary creative talent we have here in the UK. The wins speak to our unwavering commitment to backing the very best British storytelling and recognised our ability to bring people together which will be so important to us going into the future. I’m especially proud of the quality and innovation on display that really cements our reputation as the home for creative excellence and demonstrates the unique value of the BBC.
The BBC scooped a phenomenal 21 awards overall across the 30 competitive categories and dominated last night’s RTS Programme Awards.
The BBC was recognised with wins for programmes and talent across an outstanding range of impactful BBC content that captivated audiences across the UK.
Hit drama The Sixth Commandment was the most awarded programme of the night picking up three, followed by The Eurovision Song Contest and prison drama Time which both received two.
There were wins for Alex Scott, Bella Ramsey, Chris Packham, Eanna Hardwicke, Gbemisola Ikumelo, Hammed Animashaun, Hannah Waddingham, Lucy Edwards, Sarah Phelps and Tamara Lawrance.
Programmes awarded were A Kind of Spark, EastEnders, Fight the Power: How Hip Hop Changed the World, Happy Valley, Juice, Once Upon A Time in Northern Ireland, Scam Interceptors, Sort Your Life Out and the All Ireland Senior Football Championship Final.
Charlotte Moore, BBC Chief Content Officer says: “It was an incredible night for the BBC that celebrated the work of the extraordinary creative talent we have here in the UK. The wins speak to our unwavering commitment to backing the very best British storytelling and recognised our ability to bring people together which will be so important to us going into the future. I’m especially proud of the quality and innovation on display that really cements our reputation as the home for creative excellence and demonstrates the unique value of the BBC.”
